instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
This board has been through a fire!  Family friend just lost everything in a fire. I was able to retrieve the Data off of the ssd and thought I'd see if I get good karma and try and fix the Macbook too.  It looks like there is no actual fire damage just water damage.  I've put it through the Crest and afterwards it did show the low battery connected symbol but now I tried giving it some power to work on it and nothing.  

Q. Is there a sticky topic on trouble shooting power issues?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I'm going to check the one-wire circuit and it does have an green then orange light on power.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Well I guess first off I will test the MagSafe.  My schematics say 18.5v but I'm only getting 16.5v on PIN 1 and 3.6v on Adapter Sense Pin 6.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Ok well I just happened to have another Macbook same model come in and at the magsafe on logic board the voltage is 16.5v.  I guess that's normal for schematics to be off that much?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Onewire is fine you have a green/orange light. 3V on L7560 present?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Yes I have 3v on L7560

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
PPBUS_G3H   = 12.4v
PP3V3_S5       = 3.4v
PP3V42_G3H  = 3.4v

Also I no longer get the dead battery symbol when jumping the power on.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I watched a video where Louis was trouble shooting a board with no Green/orange light and he tested the PP5V_S3  ( S3 meaning sleep, correct? ) and he got 5v on that rail.   How did he get the board to be in a sleep state to test if there was 5V when the board was not powering on?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: This board should auto power on after battery was disconnected. Check PP5V_S3 carefully, it may be pulsing.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: No PP5V_S3.  Alright now where do I start to track that down?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
PP3v3_S3 is present
PPBUS_G3H = 12.4v
PP3V3_S5 = 3.4v
PP3V42_G3H = 3.4v

Just no PP5V_S3.    I wonder if I could have been an idiot and zapped something when I was trying to jump the power on at SMC on and off.  I might have accidentally touched SMC_MANUAL_RST with power.  I'm shakey with my hands sometimes.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: The enable for PP3V3_S3 and PP5V_S3 both come from PM_SLP_S4_L, so check again what is there.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Ok so I've checked but I'm not that great with schematics I guess because all I can find is PP5V_S3_RIO, PP5V_S3RSO_ALCAM, PP5V_S3_ALSCAM, etc.  No PP5V_S3 alone.  And I can't even figure out where PP5V_S3 starts to check that component.  I know how to put PP5V_S3 into Open BoardView and see all the points but that does't help if I can't trace down the path.  Thank for all the help do you happen to know the first component to check for PP5V_S3?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: So if PP5V_S3 comes from PM_SLP_S4_L then where does it do that because I can't seem to find that on the schematics?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Ok thanks for that now I see that PP3V3_S3 is not there.  Ok so I have to figure out what makes those which as you tell me comes from PM_SLP_S4_L.  Ok so now to see where that starts. When searching a schematic for PM_SLP_S4_L I get 5 pages that have it.  Is the first page where it starts and is that true of other lines when searching schematics?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I guess my question is.. how do I figure out where something is going when I'm switching pages.  Just hit the next button on the search? Thx for the help and sorry if that's a stupid question.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
Lets start over with this. 
Are you using a REAL 60W charger?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
Yes I always use real chargers with correct wattage. I've made that mistake before. Arggg ha ha let's not start over. I'm just getting the hang of where to look.  LOL!  I think I kinda get how to read the schematics now. I see the little page numbers at the end of a line and it looks like that is where those lines go to. so I can now follow the schematic. Also nothings changed other than there is no PP3V3_S3. So let's not start over.  What gives power to PP5V_S3 and PP3V3_S3?  You said PM_SLP_S4_L .   Ok so let's look at that. Looks like system power management maybe? 

I have:
Orange/Green light

PPBUS_G3H = 12.4v

PP3V3_S5 = 3.4v

PP3V42_G3H = 3.4v

PP5V_S3 = 0v (measured at Pin 1 of L4001 and many other places)

PP3V3_S3 = 0v

If I can get a direction to go for I'm happy to do the research.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
PM_SLP_S4_L cames from PCH........
Check R1300-03, voltage on both pins for all resistors (4).....

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: OMG I think I might actually be learning something.. ha I was going to check there!  Yay brain cells!  Thx

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
R1300 PIN 1. 3.34  PIN 2 = 3.33
R1301 PIN 1 = 3.34 PIN 2 = 2.98 (it moves from that to 3.03)  is that considered pulsing or just my shaky hands?
R1302 PIN 1 = 3.33 PIN2 = 3.23
R1303 PIN1 = 3.34 PIN 2 = 3.33

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: PPBUS is too low, check again it should be 12.56V. This indicates an issue with the SMC at least.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Ah ok off in search of SMC.!

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: F7140 I'm getting 12.53 for PPBUS_G3H.  Not 12.4 as I posted earlier.  Is that still too low.  Seems like 12.6v is what I want but that seems pretty close.  If it is the SMC do you think it's worth reflowing because it might just be some corrosion.  I've seen what it take to replace an SMC and I don't think I want to do that.  If 12.53 for PPBUS_G3H is good then it's back to PP5V_S3 and PP3V3_S3 not being created.  So what component creates those?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Should I try bypassing the SMC? I've seen posts about that.  IF so how would I do that?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Hi thanks for all you help. I tested F7140 and I get 12.53V for PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: 12.53 is ok for PPBUS. RTC looks fine, so this must give a pulse on PP5V_S3 when power is applied, check carefully pulses will be very short and best seen on a scope.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I don't have a scope but I can see the voltage move from 0V to .01V in a pulsing pattern.  Sorry for not having a scope that's my next purchase.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Same pulsing on CPU Vcore?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: I see from another post where 5V_S3 rails are missing that U7200 was shorted to ground.  Now I know that this board is not that board and who knows what's shorted but should I be looking for a certain rail that's shorted to ground? Thanks so much for your help Duke.  I feel like this board is being a devote christian on the first date. It's really gonna take some time to score.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Oops posted before I refreshed the page.  Cpu Vcore Rails Is PPVCC_S0_CPU , correct?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: PPVCC_S0_CPU does "seem" to pulse between .0v and .01V.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Yes is S0_CPU pulsing? What areas were liquid damaged?

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message: Hey Duke thanks again for the help.  My mom can't wait for me to fix something so that I'll move out of her garage. I'm turning 40 this week so........ anyways the whole damn board was hit with a firehose. No really it was from a fire. It didn't get hot and there was no black marks on it.  The board looked like a bucket full of shit but after the crest cleaning it did show me the battery dead symbol and after that I couldn't get it to boot.   I realize this might be a dead end but I'm really learning so much and you are the man!  Also it worked just for a second arg!  I'd really like to know what the pulse signifies.  Is that a pulse to switch states or is it a short to ground pulse?  My mom says she'll bake you extra special cookies.  I just wish she'd put on a shirt.

threads.title: 820-4924-A Power troubleshooting (Good Karma Fire damage fix)
threads.message:
If any power rails does not come high in the specified time the power up sequence will start over again. This also happens when the ROM cannot be read, clock signals are missing or pretty much any other reason. Pulsing power can therefore be anything.
Most likely areas of corrosion are around SPI ROM and clock chip or U1950. There is no easy diagnostic for this problem and even for me would not be an easy repair.
